elements.content: Dichromate (Cr2O7 2–) pillared pcu hybrid ultramicroporous materials, while previously shown to exhibit benchmark selectivity for small polarizable gases, sometimes suffer from poor stability when exposed to moisture, which could limit their potential application in gas separation systems. In attempting to improve their stability toward humidity, we have crystal engineered two new families of DICRO-L-M-i materials of formula [M­(L)2(Cr2O7)] n (M = Ni2+, Co2+; L = 5: 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­xylene; 6: 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­durene). Evaluating these materials in combination with a previously reported analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, in terms of their stability toward humidity has revealed a relationship between increasing the number of methyl groups on the dipyridyl organic linkers and a greater stability toward humidity.
elements.clean_text: Dichromate (Cr2O7 2-) pillared pcu hybrid ultramicroporous materials, while previously shown to exhibit benchmark selectivity for small polarizable gases, sometimes suffer from poor stability when exposed to moisture, which could limit their potential application in gas separation systems. In attempting to improve their stability toward humidity, we have crystal engineered two new families of DICRO-L-M-i materials of formula [M(L)2(Cr2O7)] n  (M = Ni2+, Co2+; L = 5: 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)xylene; 6: 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)durene). Evaluating these materials in combination with a previously reported analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, in terms of their stability toward humidity has revealed a relationship between increasing the number of methyl groups on the dipyridyl organic linkers and a greater stability toward humidity.

elements.content: Three families of hybrid ultramicroporous materials incorporating the Cr2O7 2− anion as a pillar are presented. An evaluation has been performed to investigate their stability toward humidity, with an increase in the number of methyl groups upon dipyridyl organic linkers found to impart greater stability.
elements.clean_text: Three families of hybrid ultramicroporous materials incorporating the Cr2O7 2- anion as a pillar are presented. An evaluation has been performed to investigate their stability toward humidity, with an increase in the number of methyl groups upon dipyridyl organic linkers found to impart greater stability.

elements.content: Crystal engineering, which describes how molecular structure influences crystal structure and physicochemical properties, has progressed to such a point that rational design strategies can be employed for the synthesis of new families of crystalline materials with desired functional properties. Metal–organic materials (MOMs), including porous coordination polymers or metal–organic frameworks, represent a broad class of materials amenable to the principles of crystal engineering.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering, which describes how molecular structure influences crystal structure and physicochemical properties, has progressed to such a point that rational design strategies can be employed for the synthesis of new families of crystalline materials with desired functional properties. Metal-organic materials (MOMs), including porous coordination polymers or metal-organic frameworks, represent a broad class of materials amenable to the principles of crystal engineering.

elements.content: Recently we have defined a subclass of MOMs combining two essential features: the incorporation of strong electrostatics, perhaps in the form of inorganic anions with electronegative atoms, and ultramicropores (<0.7 nm). We call this subclass hybrid ultramicroporous materials, or HUMs, and "have shown that they can exhibit benchmark selectivity for small polarizable gases such as CO2 and C2H2. An important feature of HUMs is that they are inherently modular, which allows for fine-tuning of structure–function relationships through substitution of one or more of their components. To date, we have identified four platforms of HUMs, each with a different class of inorganic linker: MFSIX, incorporating hexafluorometallate anions (e.g., SiF6 2–, TiF6 2–); mmo, incorporating angular anions (e.g., CrO4 2–, MoO4 2–, WO4 2–); FOXY, incorporating octahedral metal centers coordinated to O and F atoms MO x F 6−x (e.g., NbOF5 2–, WO2F4 2–); and more recently DICRO, which incorporates Cr2O7 2– anions. ,
elements.clean_text: Recently we have defined a subclass of MOMs combining two essential features: the incorporation of strong electrostatics, perhaps in the form of inorganic anions with electronegative atoms, and ultramicropores (<0.7 nm). We call this subclass hybrid ultramicroporous materials, or HUMs, and "have shown that they can exhibit benchmark selectivity for small polarizable gases such as CO2  and C2H2. An important feature of HUMs is that they are inherently modular, which allows for fine-tuning of structure-function relationships through substitution of one or more of their components. To date, we have identified four platforms of HUMs, each with a different class of inorganic linker: MFSIX, incorporating hexafluorometallate anions (e.g., SiF6 2-, TiF6 2-); mmo, incorporating angular anions (e.g., CrO4 2-, MoO4 2-, WO4 2-); FOXY, incorporating octahedral metal centers coordinated to O and F atoms MO   x   F  6-x   (e.g., NbOF5 2-, WO2F4 2-); and more recently DICRO, which incorporates Cr2O7 2- anions. ,

elements.content: We have recently shown that some members of the DICRO platform, while revealing high selectivity for polarizable gases, also suffer from poor hydrolytic stability in the presence of moisture. We therefore endeavored to undertake a systematic crystal engineering approach within the DICRO platform which saw organic linkers with varied degrees of methylation incorporated into compounds and the effects upon stability determined. This is the first example of tailoring stability toward humidity within HUM compounds, although similar work has been reported previously for microporous MOMs, whereby incorporation of methyl-, alkyl-, and fluoro-groups have been shown to increase stability in the presence of moisture.
elements.clean_text: We have recently shown that some members of the DICRO platform, while revealing high selectivity for polarizable gases, also suffer from poor hydrolytic stability in the presence of moisture. We therefore endeavored to undertake a systematic crystal engineering approach within the DICRO platform which saw organic linkers with varied degrees of methylation incorporated into compounds and the effects upon stability determined. This is the first example of tailoring stability toward humidity within HUM compounds, although similar work has been reported previously for microporous MOMs, whereby incorporation of methyl-, alkyl-, and fluoro-groups have been shown to increase stability in the presence of moisture.

elements.content: Herein we report the synthesis and structures of four new members of the DICRO platform, DICRO-L-M-i, (L = 5: 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­xylene; 6: 1,4-bis­(4-pyridyl)­durene; M = Co2+ and Ni2+) (). Analysis of structure and stability toward humidity investigated for these compounds was performed and compared with a known analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, to probe the effects of linker methylation and node variation upon stability.
elements.clean_text: Herein we report the synthesis and structures of four new members of the DICRO platform, DICRO-L-M-i, (L = 5: 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)xylene; 6: 1,4-bis(4-pyridyl)durene; M = Co2+ and Ni2+) (). Analysis of structure and stability toward humidity investigated for these compounds was performed and compared with a known analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, to probe the effects of linker methylation and node variation upon stability.

elements.content:
Self-Assembly of Organic Linkers (<bold>4</bold>, <bold>5</bold>, and <bold>6</bold>) with Cr<sub>2</sub>O<sub>7</sub> <sup>2–</sup> Pillars and M<sup>2+</sup> Nodes to Form <bold>pcu</bold> Networks<xref ref-type="fn" rid="sch1-fn1"></xref>

A second identical interpenetrated net is given in light grey to depict two-fold interpenetration.
elements.clean_text: 1  Self-Assembly of Organic Linkers (4, 5, and 6) with Cr2O7 2- Pillars and M2+ Nodes to Form pcu Networks      a A second identical interpenetrated net is given in light grey to depict two-fold interpenetration.

elements.content:
A second identical interpenetrated net is given in light grey to depict two-fold interpenetration.

Results and Discussion

Single-crystals of DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i were prepared via slow diffusion of aqueous K2Cr2O7/Co­(NO3)2 into acetonitrile solutions of ligands 5 and 6, respectively. Dark brown block-shaped crystals were obtained after 1 week. Single-crystals of Ni analogues of high enough quality for structural determination could not be obtained, and so microcrystalline powdered samples were prepared and PXRD diffractograms were matched to confirm the formation of isostructural compounds (Supporting Information; Figures S1–S4). Thermogravimetric analyses reveal that all four compounds exhibit thermal stability to at least 250 °C (Figure S5). Infrared spectra are presented in Figures S7–S8.
elements.clean_text:
a A second identical interpenetrated net is given in light grey to depict two-fold interpenetration.  

Results and Discussion

Single-crystals of DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i were prepared via slow diffusion of aqueous K2Cr2O7/Co(NO3)2 into acetonitrile solutions of ligands 5 and 6, respectively. Dark brown block-shaped crystals were obtained after 1 week. Single-crystals of Ni analogues of high enough quality for structural determination could not be obtained, and so microcrystalline powdered samples were prepared and PXRD diffractograms were matched to confirm the formation of isostructural compounds (Supporting Information; Figures S1-S4). Thermogravimetric analyses reveal that all four compounds exhibit thermal stability to at least 250 °C (Figure S5). Infrared spectra are presented in Figures S7-S8.

elements.content: The crystal structure of DICRO-5-Co-i was collected at 107(2) K and was found to crystallize in the space group C2/c. DICRO-6-Co-i was collected at 150(2) K and was found to crystallize in the space group P1̅. While the space group and unit cell parameters differ between DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i both structures are isoreticular. In both compounds the transition metal nodes are bound equatorially by four dipyridyl-based linkers, to give a sql net, which is pillared in the axial positions by Cr2O7 2–, resulting in a three-dimensional (3D) pcu topology network. The resultant network undergoes 2-fold, offset interpenetration. This mode of coordination and the presence of 2-fold interpenetration follow what has previously been described for DICRO compounds. An evaluation of structural differences between DICRO-5-Co-i, DICRO-6-Co-i, and a known analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, has been performed (see ), and these differences have been analyzed for their effect upon compound stability. Crystallographic details and a list of bond lengths and angles for DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i are given in Tables S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of DICRO-5-Co-i was collected at 107(2) K and was found to crystallize in the space group C2/c. DICRO-6-Co-i was collected at 150(2) K and was found to crystallize in the space group P1̅. While the space group and unit cell parameters differ between DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i both structures are isoreticular. In both compounds the transition metal nodes are bound equatorially by four dipyridyl-based linkers, to give a sql net, which is pillared in the axial positions by Cr2O7 2-, resulting in a three-dimensional (3D) pcu topology network. The resultant network undergoes 2-fold, offset interpenetration. This mode of coordination and the presence of 2-fold interpenetration follow what has previously been described for DICRO compounds. An evaluation of structural differences between DICRO-5-Co-i, DICRO-6-Co-i, and a known analogue, DICRO-4-Ni-i, has been performed (see ), and these differences have been analyzed for their effect upon compound stability. Crystallographic details and a list of bond lengths and angles for DICRO-5-Co-i and DICRO-6-Co-i are given in Tables S1 and S2 in the Supporting Information.

Analysis of the effects of organic linker conformation upon the overall 3D structure has also been performed. Most notably, the effect of added methyl groups results in increased distortion of the metal–organic linker coordination plane. The angle between MII–Npy–centroidC6H4 was measured to describe this distortion and was found to be nearly planar for DICRO-4-Ni-i (179.0°) but significantly distorted from planar for the others: 170.4° for DICRO-5-Co-i, and 170.0° and 172.9° for DICRO-6-Co-i.
elements.clean_text: Analysis of the effects of organic linker conformation upon the overall 3D structure has also been performed. Most notably, the effect of added methyl groups results in increased distortion of the metal-organic linker coordination plane. The angle between MII-Npy-centroidC6H4 was measured to describe this distortion and was found to be nearly planar for DICRO-4-Ni-i (179.0°) but significantly distorted from planar for the others: 170.4° for DICRO-5-Co-i, and 170.0° and 172.9° for DICRO-6-Co-i.

elements.content: Increased “bowing” between the three aromatic rings of the linker was also observed between the three families. The angle between Npy···centroidC6H4···Npy was measured to quantify the extent of bowing and was found to be 177.3° for DICRO-5-Co-i and 179.0° and 176.2° for linkers a and b, respectively, in DICRO-6-Co-i (ring labeling given in Figures S9–S11). DICRO-4-Ni-i, which does not contain methyl groups on the central phenyl ring remains essentially flat with an angle calculated to be 179.5°.
elements.clean_text: Increased "bowing" between the three aromatic rings of the linker was also observed between the three families. The angle between Npy⋅⋅⋅centroidC6H4⋅⋅⋅Npy was measured to quantify the extent of bowing and was found to be 177.3° for DICRO-5-Co-i and 179.0° and 176.2° for linkers a and b, respectively, in DICRO-6-Co-i (ring labeling given in Figures S9-S11). DICRO-4-Ni-i, which does not contain methyl groups on the central phenyl ring remains essentially flat with an angle calculated to be 179.5°.

elements.content: Differences in the torsion angles of the aromatic rings also arise between the three types of organic linkers. A table of torsion angles between aromatic rings comprising the linkers are given in to quantify these differences and ring numbering given in Figures S9–S11. For organic linkers in all three compounds, there are no aromatic rings that align within the same plane.
elements.clean_text: Differences in the torsion angles of the aromatic rings also arise between the three types of organic linkers. A table of torsion angles between aromatic rings comprising the linkers are given in  to quantify these differences and ring numbering given in Figures S9-S11. For organic linkers in all three compounds, there are no aromatic rings that align within the same plane.

elements.content: The overall effect of the increased number of methyl groups contributes to greater distortion of the metal-linker coordination plane, increased bowing of organic linkers, and more pronounced torsional twist. Collectively these features add to enhanced distortion of the one-dimensional channels running through the structure, from almost square, to distorted rhombohedral ().
elements.clean_text: The overall effect of the increased number of methyl groups contributes to greater distortion of the metal-linker coordination plane, increased bowing of organic linkers, and more pronounced torsional twist. Collectively these features add to enhanced distortion of the one-dimensional channels running through the structure, from almost square, to distorted rhombohedral ().

elements.content: View of independent nets (without second interpenetrated network) revealing differences in organic and inorganic linker orientations in DICRO-4 (left), DICRO-5 (middle), and DICRO-6 (right).
elements.clean_text: 1  View of independent nets (without second interpenetrated network) revealing differences in organic and inorganic linker orientations in DICRO-4 (left), DICRO-5 (middle), and DICRO-6 (right).

elements.content: There are less structural differences in the Cr2O7 2– moieties between families, than for the organic linkers. Notable differences are present in the measured angles associated with the bridging atom, O4. The Cr–O–Cr angle is slightly more obtuse in DICRO-5-Co-i (141.1°) than in DICRO-4-Ni-i (138.5°) and DICRO-6-Co-i (137.0°), which gives rise to a longer O1···O7 (or O1···O1′) distance in DICRO-5 (5.4 Å) versus DICRO-4 and DICRO-6 (5.2 and 5.3 Å, respectively). Additionally, when measuring the torsion angle between O1–Cr1–Cr2–O7 (O1–Cr1–Cr1′–O1′), a greater torsional twist from 180° was observed in DICRO-5-Co-i (165.0°) compared to DICRO-4-Ni-i (169.2°) and DICRO-6-Co-i (170.2°).
elements.clean_text: There are less structural differences in the Cr2O7 2- moieties between families, than for the organic linkers. Notable differences are present in the measured angles associated with the bridging atom, O4. The Cr-O-Cr angle is slightly more obtuse in DICRO-5-Co-i (141.1°) than in DICRO-4-Ni-i (138.5°) and DICRO-6-Co-i (137.0°), which gives rise to a longer O1⋅⋅⋅O7 (or O1⋅⋅⋅O1') distance in DICRO-5 (5.4 Å) versus DICRO-4 and DICRO-6 (5.2 and 5.3 Å, respectively). Additionally, when measuring the torsion angle between O1-Cr1-Cr2-O7 (O1-Cr1-Cr1'-O1'), a greater torsional twist from 180° was observed in DICRO-5-Co-i (165.0°) compared to DICRO-4-Ni-i (169.2°) and DICRO-6-Co-i (170.2°).

elements.content: Arguably the most significant difference between compounds exists in the rotation of the Cr2O7 2– about the ab plane (for DICRO-4 and -5) and bc plane (for DICRO-6) as can be seen in and . In all three families the orientation is unique. We have previously reported that Cr2O7 2– orientation in HUMs is important for fine-tuning gas sorption properties, yet difficult to control.
elements.clean_text: Arguably the most significant difference between compounds exists in the rotation of the Cr2O7 2- about the ab plane (for DICRO-4 and -5) and bc plane (for DICRO-6) as can be seen in  and . In all three families the orientation is unique. We have previously reported that Cr2O7 2- orientation in HUMs is important for fine-tuning gas sorption properties, yet difficult to control.

elements.clean_text: 2  Inorganic Cr2O7 2- pillar with atom labeling.

elements.content: 2 × 2 × 2 packing diagrams of DICRO-4-M-i (left), DICRO-5-M-i (middle), and DICRO-6-M-i (right). Void surfaces in purple determined using a probe radius of 1.3 Å, using PLATON.
elements.clean_text: 3  2 × 2 × 2 packing diagrams of DICRO-4-M-i (left), DICRO-5-M-i (middle), and DICRO-6-M-i (right). Void surfaces in purple determined using a probe radius of 1.3 Å, using PLATON.

elements.content: As mentioned previously, DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Co-i reveal 2-fold, offset interpenetration between independent networks. The offset interpenetration results in 8, 2, and 1 accessible channels per unit cell for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6, respectively, using a probe radius of 1.3 Å (representing the accessibility of H2O, based upon a kinetic diameter of 2.65 Å). As expected, the void volume decreases with the increased degree of ligand methylation, and some channels become inaccessible to small guest molecules with the protrusion of added methyl groups in DICRO-5 and DICRO-6. The void space calculated for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6 is equal to 32%, 12%, and 7%, respectively, with accessible space taking the form of 1D channels, pseudorhombohedral in shape. Along the inside of the channels and in diagonally opposite corners are MII···Cr2O7···MII chains that propagate down the direction of the channel. Because of the 2-fold interpenetration MII nodes in diagonally opposite corners are offset by one-half of the repeating segment along the Cr2O7-MII chain propagation direction.
elements.clean_text:
Shape, Size, and Chemistry of Accessible Channels Resulting from Interpenetration

As mentioned previously, DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Co-i reveal 2-fold, offset interpenetration between independent networks. The offset interpenetration results in 8, 2, and 1 accessible channels per unit cell for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6, respectively, using a probe radius of 1.3 Å (representing the accessibility of H2O, based upon a kinetic diameter of 2.65 Å). As expected, the void volume decreases with the increased degree of ligand methylation, and some channels become inaccessible to small guest molecules with the protrusion of added methyl groups in DICRO-5 and DICRO-6. The void space calculated for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6 is equal to 32%, 12%, and 7%, respectively, with accessible space taking the form of 1D channels, pseudorhombohedral in shape. Along the inside of the channels and in diagonally opposite corners are MII⋅⋅⋅Cr2O7⋅⋅⋅MII chains that propagate down the direction of the channel. Because of the 2-fold interpenetration MII nodes in diagonally opposite corners are offset by one-half of the repeating segment along the Cr2O7-MII chain propagation direction.

elements.content: Because of the unique organic and inorganic linker orientation, each DICRO family exhibits accessible channels with very different pore chemistry. For example, in DICRO-4-Ni-i there are three types of channel within each unit cell (occurring at a ratio of 4:2:2). Bridging and terminal O atoms protrude into two distinct channels, while the third is void of any O atoms. In DICRO-5-M-i, there is only one type of accessible channel per unit cell. This channel has bridging O atoms that line its wall, although the channel walls consist primarily of pyridyl groups. Similarly, DICRO-6-M-I exhibits only one accessible channel with terminal O atoms and methyl groups protruding into this channel.
elements.clean_text: Because of the unique organic and inorganic linker orientation, each DICRO family exhibits accessible channels with very different pore chemistry. For example, in DICRO-4-Ni-i there are three types of channel within each unit cell (occurring at a ratio of 4:2:2). Bridging and terminal O atoms protrude into two distinct channels, while the third is void of any O atoms. In DICRO-5-M-i, there is only one type of accessible channel per unit cell. This channel has bridging O atoms that line its wall, although the channel walls consist primarily of pyridyl groups. Similarly, DICRO-6-M-I exhibits only one accessible channel with terminal O atoms and methyl groups protruding into this channel.

elements.content: Stability testing toward exposure to humidity, using a method adapted from use in the pharmaceutical industry, was performed on the five compounds DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, DICRO-5-Ni-i, DICRO-6-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Ni-i to serve as a complementary experiment in understanding how structure impacts upon stability.
elements.clean_text: Stability testing toward exposure to humidity, using a method adapted from use in the pharmaceutical industry, was performed on the five compounds DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, DICRO-5-Ni-i, DICRO-6-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Ni-i to serve as a complementary experiment in understanding how structure impacts upon stability.

elements.content: The stability tests were conducted by exposing samples to 40 °C and 75% relative humidity. The humidity level was achieved by using a supersaturated aqueous solution of sodium chloride (NaCl) maintained at 40 °C by placing the solution in an enclosed desiccator, which was subsequently placed in an oven held at 40 °C. The time frame used for our studies was 1, 7, and 14 days. Once the sample was subjected to the desired amount of time, it was removed from the desiccator and characterized in order to detect if the sample had been affected by exposure to humidity. Characterization included PXRD, TGA, and surface area measurements. For the surface area measurements, the samples were activated under the same degas conditions (same temperature; duration of heating under vacuum) as those used for the pristine compound.
elements.clean_text: The stability tests were conducted by exposing samples to 40 °C and 75% relative humidity. The humidity level was achieved by using a supersaturated aqueous solution of sodium chloride (NaCl) maintained at 40 °C by placing the solution in an enclosed desiccator, which was subsequently placed in an oven held at 40 °C. The time frame used for our studies was 1, 7, and 14 days. Once the sample was subjected to the desired amount of time, it was removed from the desiccator and characterized in order to detect if the sample had been affected by exposure to humidity. Characterization included PXRD, TGA, and surface area measurements. For the surface area measurements, the samples were activated under the same degas conditions (same temperature; duration of heating under vacuum) as those used for the pristine compound.

elements.content: We have adopted a classification system for assessing the goodness of HUM stability under these conditions, whereby the stability grade is based upon the reduction in surface area following 14 days exposure to the above conditions and follows: 0–10% surface area reduction = good; 10–25% surface area reduction = fair; 25–100% surface area reduction = poor. For the five DICRO compounds tested the percentage reduction in BET surface area, following 1, 7, and 14 days exposure has been calculated and plotted in , and a table of surface area values also given in Table S7.
elements.clean_text: We have adopted a classification system for assessing the goodness of HUM stability under these conditions, whereby the stability grade is based upon the reduction in surface area following 14 days exposure to the above conditions and follows: 0-10% surface area reduction = good; 10-25% surface area reduction = fair; 25-100% surface area reduction = poor. For the five DICRO compounds tested the percentage reduction in BET surface area, following 1, 7, and 14 days exposure has been calculated and plotted in , and a table of surface area values also given in Table S7.

elements.content: Surface area (%) of DICRO-L-M-i compounds following stability testing. Data were collected at 1, 7, and 14 day intervals. % Surface area was calculated by normalizing “pristine” samples at 100%.
elements.clean_text: 4  Surface area (%) of DICRO-L-M-i compounds following stability testing. Data were collected at 1, 7, and 14 day intervals. % Surface area was calculated by normalizing "pristine" samples at 100%.

elements.content: The three compounds DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-5-Ni-i were found to exhibit poor stability toward humidity, with BET surface area % reductions at 14 days exposure equal to −69%, −80%, and −68%, respectively. The greater stability in DICRO-5-Ni-i vs DICRO-5-Co-i for 1, 7, and 14 days corresponds with a trend in stability (Ni2+ > Co2+) exhibited in divalent, transition metals complexes described by the Irving-Williams series. Under our classification of HUM stability, DICRO-6-M-i (M = Co and Ni) compounds revealed “fair” stability with 14 days surface area reductions equal to −25% and −24%, respectively. DICRO-6 compounds showed superior stability over DICRO-4 and DICRO-5, and interestingly the difference in BET surface area reduction between transition metals in the DICRO-6 series was reduced. The enhanced stability of DICRO-6 is thought to be a result of two features: increase in hydrophobicity of the pore by introduction of methyl groups and reduced access to pore space by reduction in void volume.
elements.clean_text: The three compounds DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-5-Ni-i were found to exhibit poor stability toward humidity, with BET surface area % reductions at 14 days exposure equal to -69%, -80%, and -68%, respectively. The greater stability in DICRO-5-Ni-i vs DICRO-5-Co-i for 1, 7, and 14 days corresponds with a trend in stability (Ni2+ > Co2+) exhibited in divalent, transition metals complexes described by the Irving-Williams series. Under our classification of HUM stability, DICRO-6-M-i (M = Co and Ni) compounds revealed "fair" stability with 14 days surface area reductions equal to -25% and -24%, respectively. DICRO-6 compounds showed superior stability over DICRO-4 and DICRO-5, and interestingly the difference in BET surface area reduction between transition metals in the DICRO-6 series was reduced. The enhanced stability of DICRO-6 is thought to be a result of two features: increase in hydrophobicity of the pore by introduction of methyl groups and reduced access to pore space by reduction in void volume.

elements.content: Two new HUM families, DICRO-L-M-i (L = 5, 6; M = Co2+, Ni2+), have been synthesized using a crystal engineering approach that exploits node and linker self-assembly. The degree of ligand methylation and its effects upon structure and stability toward humidity were investigated for these compounds and compared with a known analogous compound DICRO-4-Ni-i. The addition of increasing numbers of methyl groups to ligands resulted in increased structural distortion, but also improved hydrolytic stability. The enhanced stability with increased methylation is thought to be a result of two features: increase in hydrophobicity of the pore by introduction of nonpolar methyl groups and reduction in pore accessibility.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Two new HUM families, DICRO-L-M-i (L = 5, 6; M = Co2+, Ni2+), have been synthesized using a crystal engineering approach that exploits node and linker self-assembly. The degree of ligand methylation and its effects upon structure and stability toward humidity were investigated for these compounds and compared with a known analogous compound DICRO-4-Ni-i. The addition of increasing numbers of methyl groups to ligands resulted in increased structural distortion, but also improved hydrolytic stability. The enhanced stability with increased methylation is thought to be a result of two features: increase in hydrophobicity of the pore by introduction of nonpolar methyl groups and reduction in pore accessibility.

cln_elements.content: As mentioned previously, DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Co-i reveal 2-fold, offset interpenetration between independent networks. The offset interpenetration results in 8, 2, and 1 accessible channels per unit cell for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6, respectively, using a probe radius of 1.3 Å (representing the accessibility of H2O, based upon a kinetic diameter of 2.65 Å). As expected, the void volume decreases with the increased degree of ligand methylation, and some channels become inaccessible to small guest molecules with the protrusion of added methyl groups in DICRO-5 and DICRO-6. The void space calculated for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6 is equal to 32%, 12%, and 7%, respectively, with accessible space taking the form of 1D channels, pseudorhombohedral in shape. Along the inside of the channels and in diagonally opposite corners are MII···Cr2O7···MII chains that propagate down the direction of the channel. Because of the 2-fold interpenetration MII nodes in diagonally opposite corners are offset by one-half of the repeating segment along the Cr2O7-MII chain propagation direction.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Shape, Size, and Chemistry of Accessible Channels Resulting from Interpenetration

As mentioned previously, DICRO-4-Ni-i, DICRO-5-Co-i, and DICRO-6-Co-i reveal 2-fold, offset interpenetration between independent networks. The offset interpenetration results in 8, 2, and 1 accessible channels per unit cell for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6, respectively, using a probe radius of 1.3 Å (representing the accessibility of H2O, based upon a kinetic diameter of 2.65 Å). As expected, the void volume decreases with the increased degree of ligand methylation, and some channels become inaccessible to small guest molecules with the protrusion of added methyl groups in DICRO-5 and DICRO-6. The void space calculated for DICRO-4, DICRO-5, and DICRO-6 is equal to 32%, 12%, and 7%, respectively, with accessible space taking the form of 1D channels, pseudorhombohedral in shape. Along the inside of the channels and in diagonally opposite corners are MII⋅⋅⋅Cr2O7⋅⋅⋅MII chains that propagate down the direction of the channel. Because of the 2-fold interpenetration MII nodes in diagonally opposite corners are offset by one-half of the repeating segment along the Cr2O7-MII chain propagation direction.
